Title: Is this a measure on the sigma algebra of countable and cocountable subsets of R?
Content:
Consider the measurable space $(\mathbb{R}, \Sigma)$, where 
$$\Sigma := \{ A \subset \mathbb{R} \,:\, A \text{ is countable or } A^c \text{ is countable}\}.$$ Proving this is indeed a $\sigma$-algebra is easy: The countable union of countable sets is again countable; if the countable union contains at least one cocountable set, the coset of this union will be a subset of a countable set and thus countable. Now consider the following map: $$\mu: \Sigma \to [0,\infty], \quad A \mapsto \begin{cases}0 \quad \text{if $A$ is countable} \\ 1 \quad \text{else}\end{cases}$$ How would I prove that this map is a measure? Again, if I only consider disjoint unions of countable sets $\sigma$-additivity is obvious. But what about disjoint unions that contain uncountable sets with countable complement? I suspect that every disjoint union of sets in $\Sigma$ contains at most one uncountable set with countable coset, but I can't find a rigorous proof for this. The only uncountable sets $A \in \Sigma$ with countable coset I can picture at this moment are of the form $$A = \mathbb{R} \setminus Q,$$ where $Q \subset \mathbb{Q}$.
AcceptedAnswer: Assume that there are two disjoint uncountable sets $A, B$ with countable complements. Then $\mathbb{R} = (A\cap B)^c = A^c \cup B^c$ would be the union of two countable sets, in contradiction to the uncountability of the real numbers.
